column1: GSE6740,https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/query/acc.cgi?acc=GSE6740,PRJNA98975,Comparison of transcriptional profiles of CD4+ and CD8+ T cells from HIV-infected patients and uninfected control group,We studied a cohort of HIV infected individuals with various clinical stages of HIV infection and healthy uninfected volunteers as a control group (Table 1). We included 5 individuals with early HIV infection (A)
column2: five with chronic progressive HIV infection (C)
column3: five individuals with non-progressive HIV infection with low or undetectable viral loads (L) and five HIV uninfected individuals (N). The HIV infected individuals were never on therapy prior to entering the study. Samples were taken once from each donor.,We examined the gene expression profiles in ex vivo human CD4+ and CD8+ T cells from untreated HIV-infected individuals at different clinical stages and rates of disease progression. Profiles of pure CD4+ and CD8+ T cells subsets from HIV-infected nonprogressors who controlled viremia were indistinguishable from HIV-uninfected individuals. Similarly
column4: no gene clusters could distinguish T cells from individuals with early from chronic progressive HIV infection
column5: whereas differences were observed between uninfected or nonprogressors versus early or chronic progressors. In early/chronic HIV infection
column6: three characteristic gene expression signatures were observed: (1) CD4+ and CD8+ T cells showed increased expression of interferon stimulated genes (ISGs). However
column10: and the IL15RÎ± in both CD4+ and CD8+ T cells and the anti-HIV ISG APOBEC3G in CD4+ T cells
column11: were not upregulated. (2) CD4+ and CD8+ T cells showed a cluster similar to that observed in thymocytes
column12: and (3) more genes were differentially regulated in CD8+ T cells than in CD4+ T cells
column13: including a cluster of genes downregulated exclusively in CD8+ T cells. In conclusion
column14: HIV infection induces a persistent T cell transcriptional profile
column16: characterized by a dramatic but potentially aberrant interferon response
column17: and a profile suggesting an active thymic output.

column1: GSE7157,https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/query/acc.cgi?acc=GSE7157,PRJNA98277,Infection of Macaques with SIVmac251 in vivo,Affymetrix Rhesus Genome array were used to assay gene expression profiles at baseline
column3: 20- and 26- weeks after infection. Drug therapy started at week24,Viral infection results in an overall downregulation of gene expression that is greatest by the viral set point. Of the 3647 genes downregulated at the viral set point
column4: 1033 are upregulated as the result of successful ARV treatment

column1: GSE13824,https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/query/acc.cgi?acc=GSE13824,PRJNA110495,SIV Encephalitis and Uninfected Control: Hippocampus Expression Profiles,RNA from duplicate hippocampal samples taken from nine control monkeys and nine monkeys with evidence of SIV encephalitis were hybridized to Affymetrix arrays.,HIV-associated dementia (HAD) is a syndrome occurring in HIV-infected patients with advanced disease that likely develops as a result of macrophage and microglial activation as well as other immune events triggered by virus in the central nervous system. The most relevant experimental model of HAD
column3: closely reproduces the human disease and has been successfully used to advance our understanding of mechanisms underlying HAD. In this study we integrate gene expression data from uninfected and SIV-infected hippocampus with a human protein interaction network and discover modules of genes whose expression patterns distinguish these two states
column4: to facilitate identification of neuronal genes that may contribute to SIVE/HIV cognitive deficits. Using this approach we identify several downregulated candidate genes and select one
column6: a key molecule in hippocampus-related learning and memory
column7: for further study. We show that EGR1 is downregulated in SIV-infected hippocampus and that it can be downregulated in differentiated human neuroblastoma cells by treatment with CCL8
column8: a product of activated microglia. Integration of expression data with protein interaction data to discover discriminatory modules of interacting proteins can be usefully employed to prioritize differentially expressed genes for further study. Investigation of EGR1
column10: indicates that its downregulation in SIVE may occur as a consequence of the host response to infection

column1: GSE16147,https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/query/acc.cgi?acc=GSE16147,PRJNA115053,Microarray Expression Analysis of SIV infection of Sooty Mangabeys,We infected 5 SMs with SIVsmm and assessed their gene expression in RNA derived from whole blood at 3
column5: 30 and 180 days post-infection using Rhesus Affymetrix GeneChips. As a comparison
column6: we also analyzed gene expression in 4 RMs infected with SIVsmm
column8: a classical pathogenic SIV,Natural SIV infection of sooty mangabeys (SMs) does not progress to disease despite chronic virus replication. In contrast to pathogenic SIV infection of rhesus macaques (RMs)
column9: chronic SIV infection of SMs is characterized by low immune activation. To elucidate the mechanisms underlying this phenotype
column10: we longitudinally assessed host gene expression in SIV-infected SMs and RMs. We found that acute SIV infection of SMs is consistently associated with a robust innate immune response
column11: including widespread up-regulation of interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs). Our findings indicate that active immune regulatory mechanisms
column12: rather than intrinsically attenuated innate immune responses
column13: underlie the low immuneactivation of chronically SIV-infected SMs.

column1: GSE17626,https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/query/acc.cgi?acc=GSE17626,PRJNA118617,Lymphatic Tissues of Sooty Mangabeys and Rhesus Macaques in Early SIV Infection,We used affymetrix rhesus microarrays to profile the host transcriptional response to SIV in lymph nodes obtained from SM (Sooty mangabeys
column2: Cercocebus atys)) and RMs ( Rhesus Macaques
column3: Macaca mulatta) in the first two weeks of infection in studies described by Bosinger et al. (GEO accession number GSE16147) of the transcriptional profiles in peripheral blood. We confirm in these genome-wide comparisons that immune activation is a shared feature of early infection in the two species
column4: but show that the breadth of the changes in RMs is much greater than in SMs
column5: with evidence of positive feedback loops that amplify innate and cellular responses in RMs. We also confirm evidence of resolution of immune activation in SMs
column6: but were surprised to find little evidence at the transcriptional level of increased expression of genes that might mediate that resolution. Lastly
column7: we show that as expression of genes involved in host defenses decline in SMs
column8: there is increased expression of defensins that again may represent a species-specific host defense mechanism. Samples: 12 Sooty Mangabeys (uninfected
column10: and 30 dpi) and 16 Rhesus Macaques (uninfected and 14 dpi).,Transcriptional Profiling Reveals Distinguishing Features of Immune Activation in the Lymphatic Tissues of Sooty Mangabeys and Rhesus Macaques in Early SIV Infection Immune activation in the chronic stages of HIV-1 and SIV infection of rhesus macaques is thought to play a critical role in CD4+ T cell depletion and progression to AIDS. Conversely
column11: the lack of immune activation in the chronic stages of SIV infection of sooty mangabeys is thought to protect this species from a pathogenic outcome. This critical difference in immune activation in rhesus macaques and sooty mangabeys has recently been shown to be established in the early stages of SIV infection where there is immune activation in both species
column12: but in sooty mangabeys immune activation is subsequently resolved. Here we report the results of a microarray analysis of early SIV infection in the lymphatic tissues of rhesus macaques and sooty mangabeys that provides a comprehensive view of the distinguishing features of immune activation and host defenses in the two species. We confirm immune activation in sooty mangabeys
column13: but show that it is less robust than in rhesus macaques
column14: where positive feedback loops involving cytosolic pattern recognition receptors
column15: and chemokines and their ligands amplify the response to early SIV infection. We confirm resolution of immune activation in sooty mangabeys
column16: but show it to be partial and selective
column17: identifying the interferon system and CD38 as key correlates of outcome. We also identify potentially novel immunoregulatory mechanisms that mediate resolution
column18: and defensins as host defenses sooty mangabeys employ as expression of other innate immune system effectors declines. The studies we report here were undertaken in a collaborative longitudinal analysis of early SIV infection in SMs described in Bosinger et al and previously reported studies (Estes et al.
column22: SMs were inoculated i.v. with 1 ml of plasma from an experimentally SIVsmm-infected SM sampled at day 11 post infection
column23: with a viral load 107 copies/ml. In our studies we analyzed axillary or inguinal lymph node biopsies that had been obtained from two SMs prior to infection
column24: two SMs at the peak of viral replication at 14 dpi
column25: and two SMs at 30 dpi as viral loads were decreasing to set point. We analyzed axillary or inguinal LNs from 4 RMs without SIV infection and LNs from four RMs infected intravaginally with 2x105 TCID50 of SIVmac239 and sacrificed at 14 dpi the peak of viral replication from two cross-sectional studies described in (Miller et al.
column29: animals were anesthetized with Ketamine or Telazol
column30: the skin over the axillary or inguinal region was clipped and surgically prepped. An incision was made over the LN
column31: which was exposed by blunt dissection and excised over clamps. A portion of the lymph node biopsy for microarray analysis was snap frozen in liquid N2. All animals were housed and cared for at the Yerkes National Primate Research Center in Atlanta
column32: Georgia in accordance with the regulations of the American Association of Accreditation of Laboratory Animal Care standards. These studies were approved by the Emory University and University of Pennsylvania Institutional Animal Care and Usage Committees (IACUC). Microarray Analysis RNA extractions
column35: and data analysis followed previously published procedures (Li et al.
column43: snap-frozen lymph node was homogenized in TRIzol. Total RNA was isolated and further purified. Double stranded cDNA and biotin-labeled cRNA probes were synthesized
column44: column purified and fragmented. Fifteen micrograms of fragmented cRNA was hybridized to an Affymetrix GeneChipÂ® Rhesus Macaque Genome Array. After hybridization
column47: and scanned with GeneChip Operating Software at the Biomedical Genomics Center at the University of Minnesota. Preparation of cRNA probes and microarray hybridizations were done in duplicate for each RNA sample. Cel. files were uploaded into the Expressionist program (Genedata
column48: Pro version 5.1) and the expression level for each of the 47
column49: 000 transcripts in the arrays were analyzed using the RMA algorithm. The expression levels from duplicate microarrays of the same animalâs RNA were correlated and averaged. Tests for differences between the before and after infection at various time points were conducted using the 2-sample Wilcoxon signed-rank test. Fold differences in the level of gene expression between after infection and before infection were calculated with the ratio of the means. After statistical analysis
column50: data was sorted based on these transcript cutoffs: p-value of < 0.05 and fold change â¥ 2.0. Significantly changed genes and transcripts were uploaded into NetAffix Analysis Center (http://www.affymetrix.com/analysis/index.affx) to query gene ontology information and into Ingenuity Pathways Analysis (IngenuityÂ® Systems
column51: www.ingenuity.com) for gene annotation and pathway analysis. Hierarchical clustering analysis was carried out by using Spotfire for DecisionSite for Functional Genomics.

column1: GSE24081,https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/query/acc.cgi?acc=GSE24081,PRJNA133651,Comparison of gene expression profiles of HIV-specific CD8 T cells from controllers and progressors,We sorted HIV-specific CD8+ T cells from 18 progressors and 24 controllers
column2: cohorts with a two-log difference in mean viral load,CD8+ T cells in chronic viral infections like HIV develop functional defects such as loss of IL-2 secretion and decreased proliferative potential that are collectively termed exhaustion1. Exhausted T cells express increased levels of multiple inhibitory receptors
column3: such as Programmed Death 1 (PD-1). PD-1 inhibition contributes to impaired virus-specific T cell function in chronic infection because antibody-mediated blockade of its ligand
column4: Programmed Death Ligand 1 (PD-L1) is sufficient to improve T cell function and reduce viral replication in animal models. Reversing PD-1 inhibition is therefore an attractive therapeutic target
column5: but the cellular mechanisms by which PD-1 ligation results in T cell inhibition are not fully understood. PD-1 is thought to limit T cell activation by attenuating T cell receptor (TCR) signaling. It is not known whether PD-1 ligation also acts by upregulating genes in exhausted T cells that impair their function. Here
column6: we analyzed gene-expression profiles from HIV-specific CD8+ T cells in patients with HIV and show that PD-1 coordinately upregulates a program of genes in exhausted CD8+ T cells from humans and mice. This program includes upregulation of basic leucine transcription factor
column8: a transcription factor in the AP-1 family. Enforced expression of BATF was sufficient to impair T cell proliferation and cytokine secretion
column9: while BATF knockdown reduced PD-1 inhibition. Silencing BATF in CD4+ and CD8+ T cells from chronic viremic patients rescued HIV-specific T cell function. Thus inhibitory receptors can cause T cell exhaustion by upregulating genes â such as BATF â that inhibit T cell function.

column1: GSE29980,https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/query/acc.cgi?acc=GSE29980,PRJNA140767,Colorectal tissue gene expression in SIV negative and SIV positive Rhesus macaques and sooty mangabeys,SIV negative controls (n=4) and week 12 post SIV infected (n=4) groups of Rhesus macaques and SIV negative controls (n=4) and week 55 post SIV infected (n=4) groups of Sooty mangabeys colorectal tissue biopsies were collected in to RNA later reagent (Qiagen) and were homogenized with syringe and needle method. column2: one of the Affymetrix Microarray Core Labs.The 0.5Âµg of total RNA sample was analyzed on Rhesus Macaque Genome GeneChip that consists of over 52
column6: hybridization and post-hybridization processing were performed following the Affymetrix GeneChip Expression Analysis standard protocols. In brief
column7: The 5 Î¼g of RNA sample was first reverse-transcribed using T7-Oligo(dT) Promoter Primer and SuperScript II in the first-strand cDNAs synthesis reaction. Following RNase H-mediated second-stranded cDNA synthesis
column8: the double-stranded cDNAs were purified by use of a GeneChip sample clean-up module and served as templates in the generation of biotinylated complementary RNAs (cRNAs) in the presence of T7 RNA Polymerase and a biotinylated nucleotide analog/ribonucleotide mix by in vitro transcription (IVT) reaction. The biotinylated cRNAs were cleaned up
column10: and hybridized to the rhesus macaque expression arrays at 45Â°C for 16 h with constant rotation at 60 rpm. The gene chips were then washed and stained with Affymetrix fluidics stations 450 and scanned on Affymetrix scanner 3000. The images are processed to collect raw data with GeneChip Operating Software (GCOS) 1.4. Tissue: Colorectal tissue. Time after SIV infection: 12 weeks for SIV infected Rhesus macaques
column11: 55 weeks for Sooty mangabeys. Infection: SIVmac251 infection for Rhesus macaques
column12: SIVsm infection for Sooty mangabeys,In SIV/HIV infection
column13: the gastrointestinal tissue dominates as an important site due to the impact of massive mucosal CD4 depletion and immune activation-induced tissue pathology. Unlike AIDS-susceptible rhesus macaques
column14: natural hosts do not progress to AIDS and resolve immune activation earlier. Here
column15: we examine the role of dendritic cells in mediating immune activation and disease progression. We demonstrate that plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDC) in the blood upregulate Î²7-integrin and are rapidly recruited to the colorectum following a pathogenic SIV infection in rhesus macaques. These pDC were capable of producing proinflammatory cytokines and primed a Tc1 response in vitro. Consistent with the upregulation of Î²7-integrin on pDC
column16: in vivo blockade of Î±4Î²7-integrin dampened pDC recruitment to the colorectum and resulted in reduced immune activation. The upregulation of Î²7-integrin expression on pDC in the blood was also observed in HIV-infected humans but not in chronically SIV-infected sooty mangabeys that show low levels of immune activation. Our results uncover a new mechanism by which pDC influence immune activation in colorectal tissue following pathogenic immunodeficiency virus infections.

column1: GSE34300,https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/query/acc.cgi?acc=GSE34300,PRJNA151521,Focused examination of the intestinal lamina propria yields greater molecular insight into mechanisms underlying SIV induced immune dysfunction,3 Rhesus Macaques prior to infection and 21 and 90 days of infection,In this study three Indian rhesus macaques were infected with Simian Immunodeficiency Virus (SIVmac251). This generates a chronic infection mirroring AIDS in the animals. Prior to infection (day 0) and at two different time-points post-infection (day 21 and day 90)
column2: intestinal resection biopsies were performed. The intestinal tissue was then separated into different sub-sections including lamina-propria lymphocytes (LPL)
column4: stroma or matrix and epithelium. In this study we report the genome-wide transcriptional response at the two different time-points
column6: relative to pre-infection samples. For this purpose we have used the Affymetrix Rhesus Macaque GeneChip.

column1: GSE35460,https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/query/acc.cgi?acc=GSE35460,PRJNA152333,Gene expression profiling data from sooty mangabeys treated with interferon alpha,To directly assess the effects of an experimentally-induced augmentation of IFN-I signaling in chronically SIV-infected SMs
column2: we administered recombinant rhesus macaque IFNalpha2-IgFc (rmIFNÎ±2) to eight naturally SIV-infected SMs weekly for 16 weeks and longitudinally monitored viral load
column6: and gene expression profile. Administration of rmIFNÎ±2 was bioactive in vivo with gene expression profiling revealing a strong upregulation of numerous ISGs in the blood of treated animals.,In contrast to pathogenic HIV and SIV infection of humans and macaques
column7: SIV infection of sooty mangabeys (SMs) is typically non-pathogenic despite high virus replication. A key feature of primary SIV infection of SMs is a strong type I interferon (IFN-I) response
column8: characterized by massive up-regulation of interferon-stimulated genes (ISG)
column9: followed by rapid resolution during the acute-to-chronic phase transition and establishment of an immune quiescent state that persists throughout the chronic infection. Based on these observations we hypothesized that low levels of IFN-I signaling may be instrumental in preventing chronic immune activation and disease progression in SIV-infected SMs. We used microarrays to characterize gene expression changes induced by IFNalpha treatment.

column1: GSE51436,https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/query/acc.cgi?acc=GSE51436,PRJNA223207,Expression data from rhesus macaque tongue,Dorsal tongue tissues from healthy uninfected macaques and macaques with chronic stage SIV infection were used for RNA extraction and hybridization on Affymetrix microarrays.,A majority of individuals infected with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) have inadequate access to antiretroviral therapy and ultimately develop debilitating oral infections that often correlate with disease progression. Our study evaluates the potential of simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) infected rhesus macaques to serve as a non-human primate model for oral manifestations of HIV disease. Microarrays were used to characterize changes in gene expression in the tongue mucosa that occur during chronic SIV infection.

column5: and lung tissues from healthy uninfected macaques and macaques with chronic stage SIV infection (+/- therapy) were used for RNA extraction and hybridization on Affymetrix microarrays.,The mucosa that lines the respiratory and gastrointestinal (GI) tracts is an important portal of entry for pathogens and provides the frontline of immune defense against HIV infection. Using the simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) rhesus macaque model
column6: we have performed a comparative analysis of host gene expression in the lung and GI mucosa in response to SIV infection and antiretroviral therapy.Microarrays were used to characterize changes in gene expression in the colonic
column8: and pulmonary (lung) mucosa that occur during chronic SIV infection in the presence or absence of antiretroviral therapy.

column1: GSE57730,https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/query/acc.cgi?acc=GSE57730,PRJNA247960,Microarray analysis of whole-blood in HIV-infected Viremic Non Progressor patients,6 HIV-infected patients fitting the clinical criteria of Viremic Non-Progressors were identified. VNPs were defined as having confirmed HIV-1 infection for at least 9 years with sustained plasma HIV RNA levels >10
column2: 000 copies/ml and maintenance of peripheral blood CD4+ T cell counts >500 cells/mm3 and a CD4% (of all lymphocytes) >15%. As controls

All participants were required to be antiretroviral therapy (ART)-naÃ¯ve. RNA from 6 VNP and 7 PPs was purified from PAXgene whole blood tubes and hybridized to Affymetrix U133 Plus 2.0 arrays. During data analysis
column6: one VNP patient (PID 4015) was determined to be an outlier and removed from further analysis. Thus
column7: 5 VNPs and 7 PPs are represented in this Series.,We assessed correlates of protection from disease progression in a rare subset of HIV-infected individuals
column8: viremic non-progressors (VNPs). These individuals have high viral load for several years
column9: but in contrast to the majority of infected individuals
column10: they do not progress to AIDS. Here we found this lack of progression was associated with selective preservation of two essential subsets of memory CD4+ T cells
column11: central memory (TCM) and stem-cell memory (TSCM) cells. Compared to HIV-infected putative progressors
column12: VNPs had higher proliferation of these indispensable subsets of memory cells
column13: which was associated with the number of TCM. In addition
column14: the long-lived CD4+ TCM and TSCM cells in VNPs had decreased HIV infection compared to the less critical effector memory CD4+ T cells
column15: which indicates a possible mechanism by which VNPs maintain their CD4+ T cell pool after several years of infection
column16: and remain free from AIDS progression.

column1: GSE98717,https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/geo/query/acc.cgi?acc=GSE98717,PRJNA386019,Monocyte subsets exhibit transcriptional plasticity and a shared response to interferon in SIV-infected rhesus macaques,The progression to AIDS is influenced by changes in the biology of heterogeneous monocyte subsets. column3: and nonclassical (CD14+CD16++) monocytes may represent progressive stages of monocyte maturation or disparate myeloid lineages with different turnover rates and function. To investigate the relationship between monocyte subsets and the response to SIV infection

column8: and cell cycle inhibition. The classical and intermediate subsets are most similar at all timepoints

column11: and interferon-stimulated genes are induced in all three subsets with AIDS.
